choices.text: It has a surgically implantable titanium fixture
It transmits sound directly to cochlea through the bone conduction using the principle of osseointegration
It is indicated in patients with External Auditory canal atresia
It is not useful in patients with chronically discharging ear

questions.text: All of the following are true about bone-anchored hearing aids except
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • BAHA is given to those having discharging ears, as they cannot wear normal, conventional hearing aids.
  • BAHA - Bone-anchored hearing aid will be given to hearing-impaired individuals where conventional hearing aids can not be given, like in bilateral Anotia, EAC atresia, discharging ear, EAC stenosis. Option C ruled out.
  • A bone-anchored hearing aid is a type of hearing aid that is based on the principle of bone conduction.
  • It is primarily suited to people who have conductive hearing loss, unilateral hearing loss and those with mixed hearing loss who cannot otherwise wear "in the ear" or "behind the ear" hearing aids.

BAHA has three components:

  • titanium fixture
  • Titanium abutment
  • sound processor.

The titanium fixture is surgically embedded in the skull bone with the abutment exposed outside the skin. The titanium fixture bonds with the surrounding tissue in a process called osseointegration that takes 2 to 6 months to complete. (Option A and B ruled out)

questions.text: Which of the following is not an indication of the device shown in the image?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The image given is a Bone Anchored Hearing Aid(BAHA).
  • Bat ear is a cosmetic deformity in which the antihelix is poorly developed. We can give a conventional hearing aid to the patient if there is any need. BAHA is not needed.
  • Bone-anchored hearing aids will be given to hearing-impaired individuals where conventional hearing aids can not be given, like in bilateral Anotia, EAC atresia, discharging ear, EAC stenosis, or unilateral severe SNHL. Other options ruled out.

questions.text: What is the name of this middle ear prosthesis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

STAPEDIAL PISTON PROSTHESIS:

  • A Stapedial piston prosthesis is used in stapedectomy or stapedotomy procedures, most commonly for treating otosclerosis - a condition where the stapes bone becomes fixed and cannot vibrate properly.
  • The piston prosthesis replaces the function of the stapes by transmitting sound vibrations from the incus to the inner ear (oval window).

PORP & TORP:

Partial Ossicular Replacement Prosthesis (PORP)(Option A): Replaces part of the ossicular chain, typically when the stapes is intact.

Total Ossicular Replacement Prosthesis (TORP)(Option B): Replaces the entire ossicular chain when the stapes is not functional and when the entire ossicular chain is absent.

GROMMET:

A small tube is inserted into the tympanic membrane to ventilate the middle ear (used in otitis media with effusion).

questions.text: The titanium attachment of the floating mass transducer of the Vibrant Sound Bridge is attached to which ossicle?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Vibrant Soundbridge Device - Semi-implantable hearing aid. It has

  • Internal Component/Vibrating Ossicular Prosthesis(VORP) - Receiver, Conductor Link, Floating Mass Transducer(FMT)
  • External Component - Audio processor
  • The Floating mass transducer of the internal component is surgically clipped onto the long process of the Incus.
  • The FMT is the implantable component that vibrates in response to signals from the external audio processor.
  • These vibrations are directly transmitted to an ossicle to stimulate the cochlea.

choices.text: Persistent otitis media and mastoiditis without eradication of the disease

questions.text: Cochlear implant is contraindicated in all except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Mild intracochlear ossification is not a contraindication for cochlear implant.
  • Michel aplasia(Option A) - Complete absence of bony and membranous labyrinth. No hearing aids or cochlear implants can be used.
  • A cochlear implant works by stimulating the auditory nerve. So absence of the cochlear nerve(Option B) is a contraindication for its use.
  • Persistent otitis media and mastoiditis without eradication of the disease(Option C) - Bone Anchored Hearing Aids should be considered.

questions.text: A congenitally profoundly deaf child on radiological evaluation of the cochlea and brain with MRI/CT scan has been found to have Mondini's Dysplasia of the cochlea with the presence of a normal eighth nerve on both sides. He has shown no benefit with 6 months of hearing aid use. What is the best method of hearing rehabilitation in this case?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Cochlear implants are the best method of rehabilitation in the above scenario as there is are normal cochlear nerve and they do not benefit from conventional hearing aids.

Cochlear Implant (CI):

  • Cochlear Implant does direct Electrical Stimulation of cochlear nerve endings.

Prerequisite of CI Surgery:

  • MRI is done before surgery to look for a normal 8th Nerve.

Indication:

  • Bilateral profound SNHL (>90dB) with no improvement seen after 6 months of hearing aid use.
  • The ideal age of surgery in a child deaf since birth is one year.

A cochlear implant has 2 Components:

External component (behind pinna) - 4 parts:

  • Microphone
  • Transmitter
  • Speech processor
  • Battery

Internal component •Only one part:

  • Electrode or receiver stimulator

A cochlear Implant is of 2 types:

  • Single Channel- one Electrode, one channel to stimulate the cochlea.
  • Multiple Channel- 12 to 22 Electrode gives better results.

Candidates for Cochlear Implant are of 2 types:

  • Pre-lingual deaf - deaf since birth
  • Postlingual deafness acquired after the development of Speech shows better results.

It has 2 approaches.:

  • Trans Canal Approach( Veria approach)
  • Trans mastoid Approach

Steps of Trans-mastoid Approach:

  • Post-Aural Incision
  • cortical mastoidectomy
  • Posterior tympanotomy.

Insertion of an Electrode into the scala tympani of the cochlea through the Round window should be followed by speech therapy training.

questions.text: Identify the part of cochlear implant given in the picture
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The image shown is electrode or receiver stimulator. Which is an Internal Component.

  • Implanted under the skin behind the ear.
  • Receives signals from the external transmitter.
  • Converts digital signals into electrical impulses.

External component - 4 parts:

Microphone:

  • Captures sound from the environment.
  • Often located in or near the ear-level sound processor.

Sound Processor:

  • Processes the sound captured by the microphone.
  • Converts sound into a digital signal.
  • Often worn behind the ear or in a body-worn device.

Transmitter Coil:

  • Sends the processed signal (via radio frequency) to the internal implant.
  • Held in place over the implant using magnets.
  • Attached to the sound processor by a cable.

questions.text: Which of the following would be the most appropriate treatment for hearing rehabilitation of a patient with Neurofibromatosis type 2 with bilateral vestibular schwannoma?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Brain stem implant is the most appropriate treatment in the above case, as there are defective cochlear nerves and they do not benefit from cochlear implants.
  • Brain stem implant is placed on the lateral recess of the 4thventricle near the cochlear nucleus for stimulation.

The indications are :

  • NF-2 cases with bilateral acoustic neuroma.
  • Congenital absence of the VIII nerve.
  • Cochlear aplasia(Michel's).

Brainstem Implant:

  • A brain stem implant refers to a type of neural prosthesis or medical device designed to interact with or stimulate the brain stem.
  • It can serve various purposes, but the most common and well-established use is in the form of an Auditory Brainstem Implant (ABI).

Aim:

  • To restore a sense of hearing in individuals who are deaf and cannot benefit from cochlear implants, typically due to damage or absence of the auditory nerve (e.g., from Neurofibromatosis Type II).

Mechanism:

  • Electrodes are surgically implanted onto the cochlear nucleus in the brainstem.
  • A microphone and speech processor (external) convert sound into electrical signals.
  • These signals bypass the damaged auditory nerve and directly stimulate the brain stem.

questions.text: Parents of a 2-year-old female child with suspected Bilateral profound hearing loss attended the ENT OPD for consultation regarding cochlear implantation. All of the following investigations are part of the preoperative workup except
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Pure tone audiometry:

  • Not part of the standard workup in a 2-year-old because it requires reliable behavioural responses.
  • Typically used in older children (≥5 years) and adults.
  • Not feasible or reliable at 2 years of age.

Uses of pure tone audiogram:

  • It is a measure of the threshold of hearing by air and bone conduction, and thus the degree and type of hearing loss.
  • A record can be kept for the future
  • Audiogram is essential for the prescription of hearing aids
  • Helps to find the degree of handicap for medicolegal purposes
  • Helps to predict speech reception threshold.

Preoperative workup:

  • Auditory Brainstem Response (ABR), Option A ruled out.
  • Otoacoustic Emissions (OAE), Option B ruled out.
  • Immittance Audiometry (Tympanometry + Acoustic Reflexes)
  • Behavioural Audiometry (VRA or CPA)
  • Speech Audiometry (if age-appropriate)
  • High-Resolution CT (HRCT) of Temporal Bone
  • MRI Brain and Internal Auditory Canal (IAC), Option D ruled out.
